They would be of limited use to me and, without the carrier to put the pontoons on top, would restrict where I could go. Most of my riding is through the woods. I'd be doing a lot of sawing and hacking at that height.

Big Orn

It must be redneck. Do you actually attach basketballs to the frame?

 I don't know if they will fit other models, but on Hondas you just deflate the basketball(s), insert them into the frame (front and back) and then inflate them. Works good...once you get used to them.
 
 You gotta know how to rock-n-roll, though.

 What kind of water are you using these in? Shallow lakes, for instance? It sounds too spartan for me.
Big Orn

What kind of water are you using these in? Shallow lakes, for instance? It sounds too spartan for me.

 Creek crossings mostly. Never on large open bodies of water.
 
 You always have a small compressor on board and even a couple of those WalMart footballs, just in case. It's amazing what little you need to keep afloat in these things if you have the large mud tires. Of course you have to clean and grease more often due to all the soupy mud that gets in the most unusual places...on the rigs that is. :p
billsco

I own property on a river. I often think of ATV's I can drive across. But the banks are too steep.
 
 Drifter seems like a shallow boat landing-type craft.
Big Orn

I own property on a river. I often think of ATV's I can drive across. But the banks are too steep.

 There are quite a bit of steep banks here, but not that high. After determining the water depth, we usually lock up the brakes and slide on down. Most of the time if the water is too deep, the basketballs aren't going to keep the wheeler from going under, so we just skip to another crossing where the banks are not that steep.
 
Drifter seems like a shallow boat landing-type craft.

 Yes, you'd have to find a real good transition from bank to water.
billsco
And strike two against the Drifter: Making it a two man craft. It should be designed for a single man craft only, IMO.
jim's trucking

Back in the '50s, there was a hunting camp on an island in the Mississipppi where one of the members had a barge fitted out with a set of wheel rollers like you see at an emission testing station today. These rollers were set at the same spacing as the wheels of his old jeep and each wheel drove a paddle wheel mounted on the sides of the barge. (A four wheel drive side wheeler!) It had rudder steering that understandably wasn't very effective, but each of the rear paddle wheels had in-out splined couplings and could be individually disengaged. Shifting the jeep to 2-wheel drive disengaged the front paddles and the barge could be steered well enough.
 
 Quite inventive, I'd say. He'd just drive his jeep onto the barge, tie it down and putt over to the island, drive it off and go hunting. You might think an outboard motor or two would have done better, but it was a fairly large barge and his four paddle wheels were more effective and could move the barge even faster than he wanted to go with it.
 
 It took three people to operate it properly, but he never had trouble finding helpers...'cause his jeep was one of the only ones in the club with a cab and a heater.
